content.description:
Sustained pulling on edges and small pocketed cracks. This climber found it difficult to onsight, but will certainly be quite a good route once it sees traffic or a cleaning and once the sequence is deciphered.

Crux comes as a technical and sustained section of hard-to-see edges at around 2/3-3/4 height.

Good route. Get on it. The more traffic it sees the more it will clean up.
content.location: Third route to the right of the NBD Buttress/column. Just to the right of the side-by-side routes in the alcove.

content.description: Slippery start, then moves through dirty holds to a decent finish.  Stay on-route, unless you want to be an erosion-causing machine.
content.location: This is the route on the right side of the alcove just after the trail forks.

content.description:
Bouldery, polished start with good hands and bad feet. After the initial crux this well-protected climb angles up and left to the chains, following an ill-defined and right facing corner/ ledge system.

Worth a stop, and the best warmup on the wall, though most of the other climbs on the wall are better.
content.location:
Located about 50' right of the Naked Butt Dancing pillar and the cluster of climbs to its right. This is the second to last bolted line before starting uphill to the Endless Summer wall.

Easily identified by its leftward trend and large ledges.

content.description: Though this route doesn't look like much, it's one of the gems of the area.  It has incredibly unique moves, with a slippery start, tricky underclings and hidden jugs.  The crux is moving from the overhang onto the face.  Once you find the sequence, this climb is a pleasure.
content.location: This is the leftmost route in the overhang (just to the right of the fork in the trail).
